Open table in a new tab Having obtained genomic clones that included the first exon and upstream genomic fragments, we sequenced 450 bp of putative 5′ flanking DNA, the first exon, and contiguous portion of the first intron. The DNA sequence corresponding to the first exon matches the cDNA exactly. We used this information to accurately characterize transcription start sites by a ribonuclease protection assay using a construct that included 121 bp of 5′ flanking DNA and the first 269 bp of γENaC brain cDNA (−121+269). A single ~270-nt protected fragment was seen in human kidney and lung (Fig. 4A). The absence of a protected fragment of a larger size excludes an alternate upstream transcription start site in these tissues. The protected fragment in kidney and lung was resolved on a sequencing gel to two bands − 269 and 266/267 nt long (Fig. 4B). The larger, more abundant band defined a 5′ terminus identical to that seen in brain. A transcript was not identified in H441 cells or in renal CCD cells, probably secondary to relatively low abundance of this subunit mRNA in these cell lines. The sequence at the 5′ end of the gene was analyzed for consensus transcription factor binding motifs. As shown in Fig. 5A, the 5′ flanking genomic DNA immediately upstream of the transcription start site contains two GC boxes (GGGGCGGGGC) at −21 and −52 but does not contain a canonical TATA or CCAAT box. The transcription factor Sp1 binds to these types of GC-rich motifs and in an as yet undefined way can in turn bind to TFIID in the presence of co-activators to initiate transcription in some TATA-less promoters (31Pugh B.F. The synthesized riboprobe was designed to (i) examine whether additional upstream transcription start sites were present, (ii) to investigate the shorter primer-extended product seen in H441 cells, and (iii) to accurately localize identified start sites. We report here the genomic organization of hγENaC, defining intron-exon boundaries and portions of 5′ flanking DNA. A 650-bp region that includes ~350 bp of 5′ flanking sequence, all of the first exon, and proximal portions of the first intron is G + C rich. The Escherichia coli RuvC protein endonucleolytically resolves Holliday junctions, which are formed as intermediates during genetic recombination and recombination repair. Previous studies using model Holliday junctions suggested that a certain size of central core of homology and a specific sequence in the junction were required for efficient cleavage by RuvC, although not for binding. To determine the minimum length of sequence homology required for RuvC cleavage, we made a series of synthetic Holliday junctions with various lengths of homologous sequence in the core region. It was demonstrated that a monomobile junction possessing only 2 base pairs of the homology core was efficiently cleaved by RuvC. To study the sequence specificity for cleavage, we made 16 bimobile junctions, which differed only in the homologous core sequence. Among them, 6 junctions were efficiently cleaved. Cleavage occurred by introduction of nicks symmetrically at the 3′-side of thymine in all cases. However, the nucleotide bases at the 3′-side of the thymines were not always identical between the two strands nicked. These results suggest that RuvC recognizes mainly topological symmetry of the Holliday junction but not the sequence symmetry per se, that the thymine residue at the cleavage site plays an important role for RuvC-mediated resolution, and that a long homologous core sequence is not essential for cleavage. However, the HJs used in these studies (defined here as immobile HJs) were not substrates for RuvC, because they did not contain a homologous core sequence, which allows spontaneous branch migration of the junctions. Therefore, a question remains whether the structures of the immobile junctions are the same as the catalytically competent substrates. On the other hands, synthetic HJs that are cleavable by RuvC can branch migrate spontaneously within the homologous core sequence (mobile HJs), and experimental determination of a single mobile (catalytically competent) HJ structure among the many isomers would be difficult. In this work, to understand the RuvC cleavage requirement for the homologous core sequence and to obtain new insights into molecular mechanisms of the HJ resolution by the protein, we designed a systematic series of synthetic HJs. First, we varied the size of the homologous core sequence from 10 bp with five possible steps of branch point migration (pentamobile HJ) to 2 bp with only a single possible step (monomobile) and analyzed cleavability by RuvC. Second, the sequence specificity for RuvC cleavage was examined in bimobile HJs (4 bp of homology core; two steps of possible branch point migration freedom) with all possible sequence variations in the homologous core. We have shown that a monomobile HJ was cleavable by RuvC, and this demonstrates that RuvC introduces nicks at or 1 base away from the point of strand exchange (Fig. 6, Fig. 7). In retrospect, the large homology cores (e.g. 12 bp in synthetic HJs) previously used as substrates (Dunderdale et al., 9Dunderdale H.J. Benson F.E. Parsons C.A. Sharples G.J. Lloyd R.G. West S.C. Nature. 1991; 354: 506-510Crossref PubMed Scopus (192) Google Scholar; Bennett et al., 4Bennett R.J. Dunderdale H.J. West S.C. Cell. 1993; 74: 1021-1031Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar; Takahagi et al., 17Takahagi M. Iwasaki H. Shinagawa H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15132-15139Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) were not essential. However, not all of the bimobile HJs were cleaved; only 6 bimobile HJs among 16 possible combinations were cleaved by RuvC (Fig. 3, Fig. 4). The size of homology core sequence per se is not the key determinant of cleavage. Introduction of nicks occurred symmetrically at the 3′-side of thymine in all cases, with the nucleotide at the 3′-side of the thymine of cleavage sites varying. In addition, nucleotide bases at the 3′-side of the thymine were not always identical between the two cleaved strands (A, D, H, and P in Figs. 3, 4, 5; and Q in Fig. 6, Fig. 7). Therefore, these results suggest that the thymine residue at the cleavage site plays an important role in RuvC-mediated resolution and that RuvC recognizes mainly topological symmetry of the Holliday junction but not DNA sequence symmetry at both sides of the thymine at the cleavage site. Since some bimobile HJs with thymine in the homologous core (B, C, L, M, N, and O in Fig. 3, Fig. 4) and immobile HJs (S-X in Fig. 6B) were not cleaved, other molecular requirements in addition to the presence of thymine in the homologous core are critical for resolution by RuvC. Unlike restriction enzymes, which recognize and cleave specific primary sequences per se, RuvC may require a certain sequence context for catalysis to occur. This context may, for example, induce a certain structure that can interact productively with RuvC on forming an RuvC-HJ complex. The three-dimensional structure of RuvC has been revealed at a 2.5-Å resolution by x-ray crystallography (Ariyoshi et al., 1Ariyoshi M. Vassylyev D.G. Iwasaki H. Nakamura H. Shinagawa H. Morikawa K. Cell. 1994; 78: 1063-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). The subunits in the RuvC dimer are related by a dyad axis, and thus, the DNA binding cleft and catalytic center in each subunit are located symmetrically in the dimer (Saito et al., 13Saito A. Iwasaki H. Ariyoshi M. Morikawa K. Shinagawa H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 7470-7474Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). This relative positioning ensures the introduction of symmetrical nicks by RuvC. The computer docking model of RuvC structure with DNAs suggested that the HJ in RuvC consists of two antiparallel, quasicontinuous DNA duplexes linked with at least two unpaired nucleotides. Each DNA duplex is inclined by about 80° to the dyad axis of the dimer (Ariyoshi et al., 1Ariyoshi M. Vassylyev D.G. Iwasaki H. Nakamura H. Shinagawa H. Morikawa K. Cell. 1994; 78: 1063-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). This model of HJ differs from that of the protein-free stacked X structure of HJ proposed previously (Duckett et al., 8Duckett D.R. Murchie A.I.H. Diekmann S. von Kitzing E. Kemper B. Lilley D.M.J. Cell. 1988; 55: 79-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (413) Google Scholar; Cooper and Hagerman, 6Cooper J.P. Hagerman P.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1987; 198: 711-719Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar; von Kitzing et al., 18von Kitzing E. Lilley D.M.J. Diekmann S. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 2671-2683Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). The stacked X structure exhibits 2-fold symmetry with two strands approximating B-form DNA, whereas the complementary strands are sharply bent where they pass from one helix to the other; as a result, all of the base pairings are maintained around the junction. However, RuvC binding can convert the protein-free junction with a folded stacked X structure into an unfolded form with 2-fold symmetry with base pairings around the crossover disrupted (Bennett et al., 4Bennett R.J. Dunderdale H.J. West S.C. Cell. 1993; 74: 1021-1031Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (144) Google Scholar; Bennett and West, 2Bennett R.J. West S.C. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 252: 213-226Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). These results suggest that configuration of protein-free HJs is converted into a productive form by RuvC binding. Using synthetic HJs that are constrained to adopt defined isomeric configurations, it has been shown that the nicks are preferentially introduced into the continuous (noncrossing) pair of strands rather than the bent (crossing) pair of strands of antiparallel forms of HJs (Bennett and West, 3Bennett R.J. West S.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 5635-5639Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). The RuvC-HJ computer docking model agrees with this biochemical evidence. In it, the thymines at the cleavage sites are on the continuous strands of antiparallel forms of HJ and are positioned in the hydrophobic pocket just beside the active sites (Ariyoshi et al., 1Ariyoshi M. Vassylyev D.G. Iwasaki H. Nakamura H. Shinagawa H. Morikawa K. Cell. 1994; 78: 1063-1072Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). It has been demonstrated by a study using immobile HJs that the choice of partners of crossing or noncrossing strands is governed by the base sequences at the junction (Duckett et al., 8Duckett D.R. Murchie A.I.H. Diekmann S. von Kitzing E. Kemper B. Lilley D.M.J. Cell. 1988; 55: 79-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (413) Google Scholar). In the case of mobile HJs the partners of crossing or noncrossing strands may also be changeable during spontaneous branch migration in solution. The cleavable bimobile and monomobile HJs used in this study may be able to form such a catalytically competent structure, whereas the noncleavable ones, including immobile HJs, may not. In summary, the cleavable synthetic HJs may have the following properties: 1) thymines are positioned at or very close to the junction; 2) the strands containing the thymines are continuous (noncrossover) strands, which is governed by the sequence context around the crossover; and 3) the HJ can be converted into a productive form in the complex with RuvC, in which the thymine is in the hydrophobic pocket just beside the active site of RuvC, and base pairings at the crossover are disrupted so that the phosphodiester bond at the 3′-side of the thymine should become closer to the catalytic site. The thymine-containing sequence context around the crossover in the synthetic HJs may determine the ability to adopt such a catalytically competent configuration. This model could explain why RuvC does not cleave all of the synthetic HJs that contain a thymine at the junction. Shah et al. (14Shah R. Bennett R.J. West S.C. Cell. 1994; 79: 853-864Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) have shown that RuvC cleaves the HJs at hot spots with a consensus sequence of 5′-A/TTT↓G/C-3′ in vitro. One of our efficiently cleavable bimobile HJs, P, possesses this consensus sequence, and nicking occurred at 5′-TTT↓G-3′ in strand 1 and 5′-ATT↓C-3′ in strand 3 in this junction (Fig. 5). Therefore, their result does not necessarily conflict with our results. We have found here that HJs that do not possess the consensus sequences were still cleaved by RuvC. They used a HJ made by the RecA protein and then deproteinized. Thus, their substrate can branch migrate over a large DNA sequence, whereas our synthetic HJs have a very limited distance of branch migration, in which two junction points are possible for the monomobile HJ and three junction points are possible for the bimobile HJ. The equilibria among isomers (or choice of junction points) are governed by the sequence contexts around the encountering junction points (Duckett et al., 8Duckett D.R. Murchie A.I.H. Diekmann S. von Kitzing E. Kemper B. Lilley D.M.J. Cell. 1988; 55: 79-89Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (413) Google Scholar), and they may be quite variable. The consensus sequence might be selected by the two factors: relative stability and cleavable configuration of the junctions with the sequence (with equilibrium biased to such an isomer). However, our cleavable junctions can take only limited numbers of isomers due to the limited junction mobility, which results in relative abundance of the cleavable isomer. It is conceivable that the favorable isomers occur infrequently and rather unstably in a large Holliday structure with freely mobile junctions. We thank Drs. Kosuke Morikawa and Susan Tsunegawa at the Biomolecular Engineering Research Institute for useful discussion and critical reading of the manuscript.

The oxidation of heme by heme oxygenase (HO-1) results in highly regiospecific extrusion of the α-meso-carbon as CO and the formation of biliverdin IXα. The first step in the accepted mechanism for this process is α-meso-hydroxylation of the heme. To define further the reaction mechanism, the oxidations of the four isomers of meso-methylmesoheme by human truncated HO-1 supported by NADPH-cytochrome P450 reductase, H2O2, or ascorbate have been examined. Surprisingly, the results establish that (a) HO-1 can oxidize an α-meso-methyl-substituted heme to biliverdin IXα without proceeding via the α-meso-hydroxy intermediate; (b) the normal HO-1 α-regiospecificity is inverted in favor of the substituted γ-position by introduction of a γ-meso methyl group; and (c) the β- and δ-meso-methylmesohemes are oxidized less regiospecifically to mixtures of methyl-substituted and -unsubstituted mesobiliverdins. The results indicate that electronic rather than steric effects primarily control the regiospecificity of heme cleavage by HO-1. It is not necessary to run this reaction in the presence of CO because no reducing equivalents are present and the end product is Fe(III)mesoverdoheme. The meso-methyl-substituted hemes have been incubated with H2O2 to determine if it also supports their conversion to mesoverdohemes. The progress of the reactions of the four isomeric meso-methylmesoheme·hHO-1 complexes with a 10-fold excess of H2O2 has been monitored spectrophotometrically (Fig. 3). The earlier studies showed that the H2O2-dependent oxidation of heme to Fe(III)verdoheme results in decay of the Soret band and appearance of a broad absorption in the 600-700-nm range (10Wilks A. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22357-22362Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In contrast, incubation of α-meso-methylmesoheme with hHO-1 and H2O2 results in a peroxide concentration-dependent decay of the Soret band without the appearance of the 600-700-nm absorption (Fig. 3A). The same spectroscopic change was observed if the excess of H2O2 was increased from 10- to 100-fold. Incubation of the β-meso-methyl isomer led to a similar time-dependent decrease in the Soret band, but in this instance a small increase is observed in the 600-700-nm region (Fig. 3B). Incubation of the γ- and δ-meso-methylmesoheme isomers with hHO-1 and H2O2 gives the spectroscopic changes expected for clean conversion of both substrates to Fe(III)mesoverdohemes (Fig. 3). Thus, the δ- and γ-isomers appear to be converted to Fe(III)mesoverdohemes in good yields, but the α- and β-isomers are degraded without the formation, except for a trace in the case of the β-isomer, of mesoverdohemes. Coupled oxidation of the meso-methylmesoheme·hHO-1 complexes has been examined to determine whether it exhibits a regiospecificity pattern similar to that of the reactions mediated by NADPH/P450 reductase and H2O2. The reaction was monitored by chromatographic and spectroscopic analysis of the mesobiliverdin products. To facilitate the identification of the mesobiliverdin isomers, a regioisomer mixture was obtained by coupled oxidation of mesoheme in pyridine:water (Fig. 4B). The regiospecificity of the oxidation of each of the meso-methylmesohemes by hHO-1 was examined with the three oxidizing systems NADPH/P450 reductase, H2O2, and ascorbate. The incubations with NADPH and P450 reductase were carried out in the absence of exogenous CO, and the Fe(III)mesoverdoheme·hHO-1 complexes obtained with H2O2 were incubated with NADPH and P450 reductase prior to chromatographic analysis to convert the mesoverdohemes to mesobiliverdins. The products were analyzed by HPLC, absorption spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry. Open table in a new tab The hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of γ-meso-methylmesoheme is well behaved. A single mesobiliverdin isomer (Fig. 4D) is obtained with all three oxidizing systems, including H2O2 (Table I). Identification of this isomer as mesobiliverdin IXγ is based on its mesobiliverdin-like spectrum, an HPLC retention time similar to that of one of the isomers derived from mesoheme, and the mass spectrometric molecular ion (m/z 586) of an unsubstituted mesobiliverdin. The hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of γ-meso-methylmesoheme in all three oxidizing systems thus leads to elimination of the γ-meso-carbon and the attached methyl group. The hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of the β- and δ-meso-methylmesoheme isomers is more complicated than that of the α- or γ-isomers. The oxidation of the δ-isomer supported by all three oxidizing systems produces a mixture of mesobiliverdin products (Fig. 4C, Table I). The chromatographic resolution does not allow us to determine whether the product ratio is the same in the three systems. Nevertheless, one of the partially resolved HPLC peaks has the molecular ion at m/z 586 of an unsubstituted mesobiliverdin and is thus mesobiliverdin IXδ (Table I). The other peak, which consists of at least two isomers, has a molecular ion at m/z 600 and thus corresponds to a mixture of two methyl-substituted mesobiliverdin isomers. The hHO-1 catalyzed oxidation of β-meso-methylmesoheme supported by all three oxidizing systems rapidly degrades the heme chromophore but yields mesobiliverdin products in amounts too small for mass spectrometric characterization. An assay based on the affinity of ferrous deoxymyoglobin for CO was used to detect the formation of CO in the NADPH/P450 reductase-supported reactions of hHO-1 with mesoheme and α-meso-methylmesoheme. The assay is based on the shift of the Soret maximum of ferrous deoxymyoglobin (λmax 434 nm) on complexation with CO (λmax 422 nm). Addition of deoxymyoglobin (Fig. 5, trace a) to the mesoheme-hHO-1 reaction mixture after completion of the reaction resulted in immediate formation of the ferrous myoglobin-CO complex (Fig. 5, trace b). No detectable shift of the deoxymyoglobin Soret maximum was observed when the identical experiment was carried out with the α-meso-methylmesoheme·hHO-1 complex (not shown). Thus, CO is not detectably formed in the reaction of α-meso-methylmesoheme with hHO-1 under conditions where it is easily detected in the corresponding reaction with mesoheme. The first major finding of this study is that α-meso-methylmesoheme, like mesoheme, is efficiently and regiospecifically oxidized by hHO-1 to mesobiliverdin IXα (Fig. 4A, Table I). This finding is unexpected because the first step in the heme oxygenase reaction is thought to be α-meso-hydroxylation of the heme, a transformation that is blocked by the methyl substituent. The primary evidence for α-meso hydroxylation is the finding that synthetic α-meso-hydroxyhemes are converted to the corresponding biliverdins by HO-1 (12Yoshida T. Noguchi M. Kikuchi G. Sano S. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1981; 90: 125-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 13Yoshinaga T. Sudo Y. Sano S. Biochem. J. 1990; 270: 659-664Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 31Matera K.M. Indeed, even in the absence of HO-1, autoxidation of α-meso-hydroxymesoheme produces mesoverdoheme and/or mesobiliverdin products (14Jackson A.H. Kenner G.W. Smith K.M. J. Chem. Soc. (Lond.). 1968; : 302-310Google Scholar, 15Sano S. Sano T. Morishima I. Shiro Y Maeda Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 531-535Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 16Morishima I. The formation of α-meso-hydroxyheme in the HO-1-catalyzed reaction has not been reported, although spectroscopic evidence for its formation has been obtained. 3Y. Liu and P. R. Ortiz de Montellano, unpublished data. In any case, the oxidation of α-meso-methylmesoheme to mesobiliverdin IXα via α-meso-hydroxylation is not possible unless the methyl group is first removed. This does not occur, however, because CO is not produced in the hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of α-meso-methylmesoheme under conditions that readily produce CO from mesoheme (Fig. 5). This finding rules out oxidation of the α-meso-methyl derivative by any mechanism that implicates the α-meso-hydroxy species as an intermediate. In view of the above, α-meso-hydroxylation is either not a step in the normal catalytic process or, more likely, the oxidation of α-meso-methylmesoheme to mesoverdoheme IXα occurs by a distinct (nonphysiological) mechanism. The finding that H2O2 does not support the hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of α-meso-methylmesoheme to mesoverdoheme IXα suggests that the oxidation of meso-methylated and unmethylated substrates diverges early in the catalytic sequence. The first two intermediates in the normal reaction are the ferrous heme and ferrous dioxy heme complexes, neither of which is accessible in the H2O2-supported reaction. Reduction of the ferrous dioxy heme in the third catalytic step produces a complex formally similar to that obtained when H2O2 binds to the ferric heme. The two ferric peroxide species are unlikely to differ in other than possibly the degree of protonation of the distal oxygen. It is therefore possible that successful oxidation of the α-meso-methyl substrate by NADPH-P450 reductase but not H2O2 is due to divergence of the two reactions prior to formation of the ferric peroxide complex. This possibility is ruled out by the fact that NADPH-P450 reductase and H2O2 support the regiospecific hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of γ-meso-methylmesoheme to mesobiliverdin IXγ and mesoverdoheme IXγ, respectively. It is not clear why both oxidizing systems work well for the γ-meso-methyl derivative but only NADPH-P450 reductase works with the α-meso-methyl isomer. Nevertheless, the fact that both reactions work for the γ-regioisomer shows that the difference is not due to early intermediates of the pathway not accessible with H2O2. The abnormal degradation of α-meso-methylmesoheme by hHO-1 and H2O2 may stem from reaction of a reaction intermediate with a second molecule of H2O2. A second major finding of this study is that the regiospecificity of the HO-1-catalyzed reaction can be redirected by meso-methyl substitution. This is best illustrated by the finding that γ-meso-methylmesoheme is regiospecifically oxidized by hHO-1 to mesobiliverdin IXγ (Fig. 4D, Table I). This is highly surprising because oxidation at the methyl-substituted γ-carbon occurs despite the presence of a normal, unsubstituted α-position! The same regiospecificity is observed whether the oxidation is supported by NADPH-P450 reductase, H2O2, or ascorbate (Table I). All previous work indicates that HO-1 regiospecifically oxidizes hemes at the α-meso-position. Indeed, it has been reported that HO-1 presented with β-, γ-, and δ-meso-hydroxyhemes does not produce biliverdins in more than trace amounts, either because the corresponding verdohemes are not formed or are not oxidized further (13Yoshinaga T. Sudo Y. Sano S. Biochem. J. 1990; 270: 659-664Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The basis for the regiospecificity of HO-1 is not known, but the regiochemistry of the coupled oxidation of the heme in sperm whale myoglobin and human hemoglobin has led to the proposal that the reaction regiospecificity is controlled by steric orientation of the ferrous dioxygen complex (32Brown S.B. Chabot A.A. Enderby E.A. North A.C.T. Nature. 1981; 289: 93-95Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The present results are inconsistent with such a steric control mechanism. Although meso-methyl substitution causes ruffling of the porphyrin ring (33Senge M.O. Ema T. Smith K.M. J. Chem. Soc. Chem. Commun. 1995; : 733-734Crossref Google Scholar, 34Medforth C.J. Senge M.O. Smith K.M. Sparks L.D. Shelnutt J.A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992; 114: 9859-9869Crossref Scopus (350) Google Scholar), it is highly unlikely that γ-meso-methyl substitution could so alter the steric interactions as to produce a clean 180° inversion in the reaction regiospecificity. Although steric steering may play some role, the meso-methylmesoheme results suggest that electronic effects play a dominant role in controlling the HO-1 regiospecificity. Thus, electron donation by a methyl substituent, possibly strengthened by ruffling of the porphyrin, should enhance the reactivity of the substituted meso- position. Two independent pieces of evidence support such a mechanism. First, studies of the ethylhydroperoxide-dependent oxidation of heme by hHO-1 suggest that the oxygen adds electrophilically to the α-meso-position (35Wilks A. Torpey J. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29553-29556Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Electron donating substituents should therefore, as observed, facilitate reaction at the substituted position. Second, the 1H NMR spectrum of the hHO-1·heme complex provides evidence for a distinctive distribution of electron density in the highest occupied porphyrin molecular orbital. This electron distribution is seen when electron donating or withdrawing substituents are placed on the meso-carbons of the porphyrin (36Herná;ndez G. Wilks A. Paolesse R. Smith K.M. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. La Mar G.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6631-6641Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). This finding has led to the proposal that the HO-1 protein perturbs the heme electronic distribution to favor α-meso-hydroxylation. Additional support for electronic control of the reaction regiochemistry is provided by the lower regiospecificity of the hHO-1-catalyzed oxidation of β- and δ-meso-methylmesoheme (Fig. 4C, Table I). In particular, oxidation of the δ-isomer proceeds with mixed regiochemistry to give both mesobiliverdin IXδ and mesobiliverdins that retain the δ-methyl group (Table I). The products with the methyl group probably derive from oxidation of the heme at the α- and γ-positions, since oxidation of the β-position gives very low yields of biliverdin products. This lower reaction regiospecificity may reflect a competition between the protein-mediated electronic effects that promote reaction at the α-meso-position and the conflicting enrichment by the methyl group of electron density at the δ-meso-position. A comparable conflict in the reaction regiochemistry is not observed when the methyl is at the γ-meso-position because electronic perturbations of the type suggested by the hHO-1 NMR spectrum are symmetry-related (36Herná;ndez G. Wilks A. Paolesse R. Smith K.M. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. La Mar G.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6631-6641Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 37Tan H. Simonis U. Shokhirev N.V. Walker F.A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1994; 116: 5784-5790Crossref Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 38Lin Q. Simonis U. Tipton A.R. Norvell C.J. Walker F.A. Inorg. Chem. 1992; 31: 4216-4217Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar). That is, meso-positions opposite to each other with respect to the iron are similarly affected by meso-substitutions, although the magnitude of the effect at the two sites differs. The α- and γ-positions, and the β- and δ-positions, should therefore be paired in their response to meso-substitution. In this correlation, it is clear that the β-meso-position is unique in that its oxidation by hHO-1 primarily yields products other than mesoverdoheme (or mesobiliverdin) whether it is methyl-substituted or not. The abnormal β-meso reactivity is of further interest because NMR studies show that heme is bound in the hHO-1 active site in two orientations related to each other by a 180° rotation about the α-γ axis. This rotation exchanges the β- and δ-meso-carbons (36Herná;ndez G. Wilks A. Paolesse R. Smith K.M. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. La Mar G.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6631-6641Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar). The heme was found in approximately a 1:1 distribution between the two orientations. If a similar binding heterogeneity exists for β-meso-methylmesoheme, the β-methyl should be located partially in the “β-site” and partially in “δ-site.” As the δ-meso-methyl isomer is readily oxidized, one might expect that the fraction of the β-meso-methyl isomer with the β-meso-carbon in the δ-site should be similarly oxidized. Indeed, it is possible that the small extent to which the β-meso-methyl isomer is oxidized to a mesobiliverdin may reflect the proportion of the substrate bound in the “inverted” orientation. As the earlier NMR evidence showed that the ratio of the binding orientations is sensitive to the nature of the 2,4-substituents on the porphyrin (36Herná;ndez G. Wilks A. Paolesse R. Smith K.M. Ortiz de Montellano P.R. La Mar G.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6631-6641Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), it is plausible that β-meso-methylmesoheme binds primarily in an unproductive orientation and only to a small extent in the productive inverted orientation. In sum, the present studies demonstrate that meso-hydroxylation is not absolutely required for the HO-1-catalyzed cleavage of heme groups and establish that the regiospecificity of the enzymatic reaction is more influenced by electronic than steric factors. The finding that the same regioselectivity is observed whether the reaction is supported by NADPH-P450 reductase, H2O2, or ascorbate strengthens the conclusion that the factors that determine the regiospecificity are not related to the oxygen activation mechanism but are inherent to the binding of the heme in the active site. Detailed mechanistic studies currently in progress, including efforts to determine the fate of the two carbons removed from the substrate in the oxidative reaction, should further clarify both the mechanism of the reaction by which the methyl-substituted meso-carbon is excised and the relationship of this reaction to the normal catalytic turnover of HO-1. The c-cbl protooncogene product (p120cbl) is a known substrate of multiple tyrosine kinases. It is found in complexes with critical signal transduction molecules, including the linker protein Grb2. Here, we demonstrate using an immobilized Grb2-binding peptide that the Grb2-p120cbl complex dissociates in vivo following engagement of the T-cell antigen receptor in Jurkat T-cells. The early kinetics of this dissociation correlate with the known time course of tyrosine phosphorylation of p120cbl and other substrates. This dissociation persists in vivo even when p120cbl becomes dephosphorylated to basal levels. However, this decreased association is not observed in protein overlay assays on nitrocellulose membranes in which a Grb2 fusion protein is used to detect p120cbl from stimulated or unstimulated cells. These data suggest that the tyrosine phosphorylation of p120cbl does not completely account for the regulation of its association with Grb2. Additionally, we used truncation mutations of p120cbl to map the p120cbl-Grb2 interaction to amino acids 481-528 of p120cbl; this interaction is stronger in longer constructs that include additional proline-rich motifs. The in vivo regulation of the Grb2-p120cbl complex further supports the idea of a significant role for p120cbl in receptor-mediated signaling pathways. The ubiquitously expressed G-proteins G12 and G13 whose function is currently not clear have been shown to be activated in platelet membranes through receptors that stimulate platelet aggregation. We used intact human platelets to determine whether α subunits of both G-proteins can be phosphorylated under physiological conditions. Activation of human platelets by thrombin and the thromboxane A2 receptor agonist U46619 lead to phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13. Phosphorylation occurred rapidly after addition of thrombin and was not mediated by glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (integrin αIIbβ3) activation. Phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 could be mimicked by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, and thrombin-induced phosphorylation was inhibited by the protein kinase C inhibitor calphostin C indicating an involvement of protein kinase C in Gα12/13 phosphorylation induced by thrombin in human platelets. The phosphorylation of both G protein α subunits was reconstituted in COS-7 cells cotransfected with Gα12 or Gα13 and different protein kinase C isoforms. Among the protein knase C isoforms tested, protein kinase C β, δ, and ϵ were most effective in promoting phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 in a phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate-dependent manner. These data demonstrate that Gα12 and Gα13 are phosphorylated under in vivo conditions and that this phosphorylation involves protein kinase C. Platelets are a well described model system for studies of G-protein mediated signal transduction processes. In human platelet membranes both, Gα12 and Gα13, have been shown to be activated through thrombin and thromboxane A2 receptors (19Offermanns S. Laugwitz K.L. Spicher K. Schultz G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 504-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar). We therefore chose intact human platelets to test whether Gα12 and Gα13 can be phosphorylated under in vivo conditions. Our data show that treatment of human platelets with physiological platelet activators leads to a rapid and sustained phosphorylation of both G-protein α-subunits and that this phosphorylation is mediated by protein kinase C. Time course experiments revealed a rapid and sustained phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 in response to thrombin (Fig. 3). Phosphorylation of both proteins was maximal 10 s after addition of thrombin, whereas phosphorylation in response to PMA was maximal not earlier than 2 min after PMA was added. To rule out that phosphorylation of both proteins was dependent on activation of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (integrin αIIbβ3) we incubated platelets with the peptide RGDS prior to addition of thrombin (Fig. 4). Pretreatment of platelets with RGDS, an inhibitor of αIIbβ3-fibrinogen binding, had no effect on the thrombin induced phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13, whereas it prevented formation of a platelet aggregate which was usually visible about 3-4 min after addition of thrombin. Thus, thrombin induced Gα12 and Gα13 phosphorylation is an event occurring early during platelet activation. Fig. 6 shows that expression of different protein kinase C isoforms in COS-7 cells resulted in increased basal protein kinase C activity measured in permeabilized cells using PKC substrate peptides. Incubation of cells with the phorbol ester PMA increased the protein kinase C activity in cells expressing the protein kinase C isoforms α, β, δ, ϵ, and η, whereas the kinase activity in cells transfected with the atypical PKC isoform ζ was unresponsive to PMA. We then coexpressed individual PKC isoforms and Gα12 or Gα13 and measured the phosphorylation of both G-protein α-subunits in response to PMA (Fig. 7). In metabolically labeled COS-7 cells transfected only with a control plasmid encoding β-galactosidase and incubated in the presence of PMA, no phosphorylated Gα12 or Gα13 was immunoprecipitated, whereas in cells transfected with Gα12 or Gα13, PMA induced the phosphorylation of both proteins presumably through the activation of endogenous protein kinase C. This PMA-induced phosphorylation of Gα12 as well as of Gα13 was unchanged in cells coexpressing the PKC isoforms α and η, indicating that these PKC isoforms were unable to mediate the effect of PMA on phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 in our cotransfection system. However, in cells cotransfected with PKCβ, δ, or ϵ and Gα12 or Gα13 PMA-induced phosphorylation of each G-protein α-subunit was increased compared to cells transfected only with the Gα-subunit. The amount of Gα12 and Gα13 expressed in different cotransfected cells was the same when tested by Western blotting of cell lysates (data not shown). Quantification of radioactivity incorporated into Gα12 and Gα13 by using the PhosphorImager showed that PMA stimulated phosphorylation about 4.5-fold in cells expressing PKCβ compared to control cells, whereas PMA stimulated phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 in cells cotransfected with PKCδ and ϵ was slightly lower (2-3.5-fold). These data demonstrate that the PKC-dependent phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 observed in human platelets can be reconstituted by cotransfection of different PKC isoforms and both G-protein α-subunits in COS-7 cells. The object of this study was to test whether members of the Gα12 family can be phosphorylated under physiological conditions. Human platelets were used as an experimental system since they contain both Gα12 and Gα13 as well as a variety of well described signaling pathways. We demonstrate that in human platelets both Gα12 and Gα13 undergo phosphorylation in response to the platelet activators thrombin and thromboxane A2. Phosphorylation occurred independent of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (integrin αIIbβ3) activation and was maximal within seconds after addition of thrombin to platelets, indicating that it is an event occurring during the first phase of platelet activation. Phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 could also be observed after addition of phorbol ester PMA, and thrombin induced phosphorylation was blocked by the protein kinase C inhibitor calphostin C, strongly suggesting that phosphorylation of both G-proteins involves protein kinase C. In analogy to Gαz we mutagenized Ser31 of Gα13 which corresponds to Ser16 in Gαz as well as Ser39 of Gα13 which also lies in the domain which is thought to contact Gβγ. Both the single mutants as well as the double mutant were, however, still phosphorylated in response to phorbol esters when expressed in COS-7 cells (data not shown), indicating that phosphorylation of Gα13 occurs at different residues and that the functional consequences of Gα13 phosphorylation are probably different from those of Gαz phosphorylation. G12 and G13 have been shown to be activated via thrombin and thromboxane A2 receptors in human platelet membranes (19Offermanns S. Laugwitz K.L. Spicher K. Schultz G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 504-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar), suggesting that both G-proteins are involved in the activation of platelets. Interestingly, both receptors as shown in the present study induce phosphorylation of both G-protein α-subunits in intact human platelets. Both receptors also activate Gq family members leading to the activation of PLCβ and the subsequent rise in [Ca2+]i and PKC activation. Thus, it is possible that thrombin and thromboxane A2 induced Gα12/13 phosphorylation in platelets results from activation of PLCβ by Gαq representing “cross-talk” between the Gq/PLCβ pathway and G12/13. Constitutively active mutants of Gα12 and Gα13 were recently shown to stimulate stress fiber formation and focal adhesion assembly through the small guanine nucleotide binding protein Rho in Swiss 3T3 cells, whereas activated forms of Gαq or Gαi2 had no effect (18Buhl A.M. Johnson M.L. Dhanasekaran N. Johnson G.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 24631-24634Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (420) Google Scholar). Aggregation of platelets in response to thrombin has been found to be inhibited by Clostridium botulinum C3 exoenzym, which ADP-ribosylated and inhibits Rho (32Morii N. Teru-uchi T. Tominaga T. Kumagai N. Kozaki S. Ushikubi F. Narumiya S. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20921-20926Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, mediating the activation of Rho in platelets exposed to thrombin is a possible function of Gα12 and Gα13. A striking feature of Gα12 and Gα13 studied in purified form is their low rate of guanine nucleotide turnover (20Singer D.W. Miller T.R. Sternweis P.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 19796-19802Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Kozasa T. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1734-1741Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (294) Google Scholar). Similarly, both α-subunits showed a very slow rate of GTP binding in platelet membranes; GTP binding stimulated through the thromboxane A2 and thrombin receptor reached a maximum only after 30 min (19Offermanns S. Laugwitz K.L. Spicher K. Schultz G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 504-508Crossref PubMed Scopus (385) Google Scholar). This guanine nucleotide exchange rate seems to be far to slow to allow Gα12 and Gα13 to play a significant role during platelet activation which takes place within a few minutes. There might be mechanisms leading to a faster activation of G12 and G13 which eluded experimental analysis in cell free systems. It is tempting to speculate that the rapid phosphorylation of Gα12 and Gα13 we observed in activated platelets may be part of a mechanism which leads to a faster activation of G12/13 and triggers or sustains their function in platelet activation. Taken together, we provide evidence that Gα12 and Gα13 are rapidly phosphorylated in activated platelets in a PKC-dependent manner and that this in vivo phosphorylation can be reconstituted in a cotransfected system. Once, the effector function directly regulated by G-proteins of the Gα12 family has been characterized, the effect of PKC-mediated phosphorylation on G12/13 signaling can be determined. Shc is involved in the activation of Ras in response to many growth factors. Shc contains two phosphotyrosine binding domains, an Src homology 2 (SH2) domain in the carboxyl terminus of the protein and a phosphotyrosine binding (PTB) domain in the amino terminus. Since functional roles for these two domains have not been established, we microinjected glutathioneS-transferase fusion proteins of either the Shc PTB or SH2 domains into fibroblasts expressing insulin and epidermal growth factor receptors and measured their effects on DNA synthesis. We found that the Shc PTB was necessary for insulin-induced mitogenic signaling, whereas the SH2 domain was not. In contrast, for epidermal growth factor signaling, the Shc SH2 was functionally more important. These differential modes of signal transduction may be an important factor in determining the specificity of the response of a cell to external stimuli. The cysteine present in the Ig μ chain tailpiece (μtp) prevents the secretion of unpolymerized IgM intermediates and causes their accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). In principle, this can be the consequence of actual retention in this organelle or of retrieval from the Golgi. To determine which of the two mechanisms underlies the cysteine-dependent ER localization, we analyze here the post-translational modifications of suitably engineered cathepsin D (CD) molecules. The glycans of this protease are phosphorylated by post-ER phosphotransferases and further modified in the trans-Golgi to generate a mannose 6-phosphate lysosome targeting signal. Only trace amounts of the μtp-tagged CD (CDMμtpCys) are phosphorylated, unless retention is reversed by exogenous reducing agents or the critical cysteine mutated (CDMμtpSer). In contrast, a KDEL-tagged CD, that is retrieved from the Golgi into the ER, acquires phosphates, though mainly resistant to alkaline phosphatase. Similarly to CDMμtpSer, the few CDMμtpCys molecules that escape retention and acquire phosphates in the cis-Golgi are transported beyond the KDEL retrieval compartment, as indicated by their sensitivity to alkaline phosphatase. These results demonstrate that the thiol-dependent ER localization arises primarily from true retention, without recycling through the Golgi. Thrombin, via activation of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cell thrombin receptors, modulates vascular wall healing. To understand the mechanisms that regulate human thrombin receptor (HTR) expression, we cloned and characterized the HTR gene. The HTR gene consists of Exon I, which contains the 5′-regulatory region and 85 nucleotides of coding sequence; a ~15-kb intron; and Exon II, which contains the remainder of the coding sequence and the entire 3′-untranslated region. Multiple transcription initiation sites were identified by S1 mapping and ribonuclease protection assay. DNA sequence analysis indicated the presence of two SP-1-AP-2 consensus binding sequences, near or within the transcription initiation sites, and consensus binding sequences for numerous regulatory proteins that potentially modulate HTR expression. Functional analysis of the HTR promoter was performed by transfecting human microvascular endothelial cells with HTR promoter region-luciferase constructs. The highest level of expression was obtained with a 0.7-kb promoter sequence and was progressively less with fragments of 0.54, 1.16, 1.6, and ~3.2 kb. The data presented in this report provide a foundation for further characterization of the HTR gene and the mechanisms that regulate its expression within the blood vessel wall. Here we report the structural organization and promoter activity of the HTR gene. The genomic organization of the HTR gene consists of two exons, and a single intron that is ~15 kb in size. DNA sequencing of 2.8 kb upstream of the translation initiation codon, the putative regulatory region, reveals no open reading frames and shows multiple potential nuclear protein binding motifs. The presence of several potential antioxidant response elements (AREs) in the proximal promoter region is consistent with the observed redox-sensitive modulation of HTR expression in vitro. Both S1 mapping and RNase protection assay locate multiple transcription initiation sites, consistent with the absence of a TATA box sequence within the proximal promoter. Functional analysis of the regulatory region of the HTR gene indicates significant promoter activity present within 0.54 kb upstream of the translation initiation codon and maximal activity present in a 0.7-kb promoter construct. In a previous study (Hardy et al. (1994) J. Biol. Chem. 269, 18535-18540), we observed that the manganese-based superoxide dismutase mimetic Mn(II)-dichloro(1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclopentadecane) (MnPAM) inhibited neutrophil-mediated cell injury in vitro. We have extended these studies with the low molecular weight superoxide dismutase mimic to evaluate the role of superoxide in neutrophil-mediated tissue injury in vivo. In a dose-dependent manner, MnPAM inhibited colonic tissue injury and neutrophil accumulation into the colonic tissue induced by the intracolonic instillation of dilute aqueous acetic acid in mice. Tissue injury was assessed by visual and histological analysis. Neutrophil infiltration was determined by tissue myeloperoxidase activity and confirmed by histological analysis. Two novel Mn(II) dichloro complexes of the carbon-substituted macrocycles 2-methyl-1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclopentadecane (MnMAM) and 2-(2-methylpropyl)-1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclopentadecane (MnBAM) effectively catalyzed the dismutation of superoxide with catalytic rate constants (kcat) of 3.31 × 107M−1 s−1 and 1.91 × 107M−1 s−1, respectively, as determined by stopped-flow kinetic analysis at pH 8.1 and 21°C. The superoxide dismutase mimetics MnMAM and MnBAM also attenuated dilute aqueous acetic acid-induced tissue injury and neutrophil infiltration into colonic tissue; however, two Mn(II) complexes that had little or no detectable SOD activity (kcat≤ 0.1 × 107M−1 s−1), specifically the Mn(II) dichloro complexes of 1,4,7,10,13-pentaazacyclohexadecane and 1,4,7,11,14-pentaazacycloheptadecane, failed to inhibit the colonic tissue injury or infiltration of neutrophils in mice treated intracolonically with dilute aqueous acetic acid. These results are consistent with a proinflammatory role for superoxide in the mediation of neutrophil infiltration in vivo.

We have reported the localization on yeast microsomes for a modified P450c27 (mic-P450c27) that contains the microsomal targeting signal of bovine P450c17 in front of the mature form of rat mitochondrial P450c27 (Sakaki, T., Akiyoshi-Shibata, M., Yabusaki, Y., and Ohkawa, H. (1992) J. Biol. Chem. 267, 16497-16502). In this study, we found that mic-P450c27 could be reduced by NADPH in the yeast microsomes without supplement of its physiological redox partners, adrenodoxin and NADPH-adrenodoxin reductase. In order to elucidate the direct electron transfer from NADPH-P450 reductase to mic-P450c27, we carried out simultaneous expression of mic-P450c27 and yeast P450 reductase. The reduction rate of mic-P450c27 was increased by overproduction of yeast P450 reductase, roughly in proportion to the reductase content in the microsomes. In addition, we constructed a fused enzyme between mic-P450c27 and yeast P450 reductase. The reduction rate of heme iron in the fused enzyme was too rapid to be measured. These recombinant yeast microsomes showed a notable 27-hydroxylation activity toward 5β-cholestane-3α,7α,12α-triol in the absence of adrenodoxin and adrenodoxin reductase. Finally, we purified mic-P450c27 from the recombinant yeast microsomes and reconstituted the hydroxylation system in liposomal membranes using the purified mic-P450c27 and yeast NADPH-P450 reductase. Mic-P450c27 was reduced by NADPH and showed its monooxygenase activity on the reconstituted system. Therefore, yeast NADPH-P450 reductase alone was found to transfer two electrons from NADPH to mic-P450c27. These results clearly show that mic-P450c27 not only localizes on the microsomes but also functions as a microsomal cytochrome P450 that accepts electrons from NADPH-P450 reductase. Cytochrome P450 represents a large group of structurally related hemoproteins that catalyze the monooxygenase reactions of a wide variety of both endogenous and exogenous compounds. P450 monooxygenases can be classified into two types based on the electron supplying proteins to P450. In class I P450s (1Ravichandran K.G. Boddupali S.S. Hasemann C.A. Peterson J.A. Deisenhofer J. Science. 1993; 261: 731-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (901) Google Scholar), which include most of bacterial soluble P450s and mitochondrial P450s, the electron transport chain involves an FAD-containing enzyme, ferredoxin reductase, and an iron-sulfur enzyme, ferredoxin, to transfer electrons from NADH or NADPH to the terminal P450. In class II P450s, which include microsomal P450s and bacterial P450BM-3 (2Fulco A.J. Ruttinger R.T. Life Sci. 1987; 40: 1754-1769Crossref Scopus (18) Google Scholar), electrons are transferred from NADPH to P450 by the catalysis of NADPH-P450 reductase that contains one molecule each of FAD and FMN. Although detailed studies have been carried out for the interaction between the P450s and their partner proteins in the both electron transfer systems (1Ravichandran K.G. Boddupali S.S. Hasemann C.A. Peterson J.A. Deisenhofer J. Science. 1993; 261: 731-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (901) Google Scholar, 3Coghlan V.M. Vickery L.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 18606-18612Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 4Furuya H. Shimizu T. Hirano K. Hatano M. Fujii-Kuriyama Y. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 6848-6857Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar), the interaction between mitochondrial P450s and the NADPH-P450 reductase or between microsomal P450s and the ferredoxin has not been well demonstrated yet. Recently, Jenkins and Waterman (5Jenkins C.M. Waterman M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 27401-27408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) reported a very interesting finding for the electron transfer system to heterologously expressed P450c17 in Escherichia coli. They purified both an FMN-containing flavodoxin and an FAD-containing NADPH-flavodoxin reductase from E. coli and found that these enzymes could support 17α-hydroxylation activity of bovine adrenal microsomal P450c17, which explains well why P450c17 expressed in E. coli is functionally active without P450 reductase (6Barnes H.J. Arlotto M.P. Waterman M.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 5597-5601Crossref PubMed Scopus (519) Google Scholar). From an evolutionary standpoint, microsomal P450 is thought to have diverged from a bacterial soluble P450, followed by the appearance of mitochondrial P450 from microsomal P450 (7Nebert D.W. Nelson D.R. Estabrook R.W. Feyereisen R. Fujii-Kuriyama Y. Gonzalez F. Guengerich F.P. Gunsalus I.C. Johnson E.F. Loper J.C. Sato R. Waterman M.R. Waxman D.J. DNA Cell Biol. 1991; 10: 1-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (808) Google Scholar). Alteration of soluble P450 to microsomal one could be explained by the addition of an amino-terminal hydrophobic sequence to the soluble P450 and that of microsomal P450 to mitochondrial one could be attributed to the substitution of the signal sequence for the localization into the mitochondrial inner membranes. Indeed, we have succeeded in conversion of subcellular localization of P450c27 from yeast mitochondria to microsomes only by altering its amino-terminal targeting signal (8Sakaki T. Akiyoshi-Shibata M. Yabusaki Y. Ohkawa H. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 16497-16502Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, no possible schemes have been suggested for the evolution or alteration of the electron transfer partners to P450. 5β-cholestane-3α,7α,12α-triol NADPH-adrenodoxin reductase adrenodoxin. In the present study, we examined by the use of molecular engineering methods whether mic-P450c27 could accept electrons efficiently from yeast NADPH-P450 reductase. In addition, we have constructed a highly active fused enzyme between mic-P450c27 and yeast P450 reductase. These findings clearly indicated that yeast P450 reductase can transfer electrons from NADPH directly to mic-P450c27. Kominami S. Takemori S. Ohkawa H. Akiyoshi-Shibata M. Yabusaki Y. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4933-4939Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). These findings suggest the existence of the electron donor protein(s) to mic-P450c27 on the yeast microsomal membrane. In order to confirm the electron transfer from NADPH-P450 reductase to mic-P450c27, we first constructed the simultaneous expression plasmid pAMS25R for mic-P450c27 and yeast P450 reductase. The resulting AH22/pAMS25R strain contained a 24-fold increased amount of the reductase as compared with AH22/pAMS25 cells. The reduction rate of mic-P450c27 heme iron in AH22/pAMS25R microsomes was 17-fold more rapid than mic-P450c27 in AH22/pAMS25 microsomes, roughly in proportion to the reductase content. In addition, AH22/pAMS25R microsomes showed THC 27-hydroxylation activity without addition of ADX and ADR. These results strongly support our hypothesis that mic-P450c27 can accept two electrons from P450 reductase in the P450 reaction cycle. Next, we constructed the fused enzyme between mic-P450c27 and yeast NADPH-P450 reductase to further investigate the electron transfer from NADPH through P450 reductase to mic-P450c27. The rate of the first electron transfer from NADPH to the heme iron was too rapid to be measured, as was the case for the fused enzyme between rat P4501A1 and yeast P450 reductase (17Sakaki T. Kominami S. Takemori S. Ohkawa H. Akiyoshi-Shibata M. Yabusaki Y. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4933-4939Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). In addition, the fused enzyme showed a 5-fold higher THC 27-hydroxylation activity than mic-P450c27 in AH22/pAMS25R microsomes. Ohyama Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 18138-18142Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and that of the present study may be attributable to the amount of P450 reductase used for reconstitution. As compared with the reconstituted system used by Okuda et al. (24Okuda K. Masumoto O. Ohyama Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 18138-18142Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we employed equal or more amounts of yeast P450 reductase for the reconstitution of the liposomal membranes and for coexpression in the present study. Pember S.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 5596-5602Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 30Guengerich F.P. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 2811-2820Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). As shown in the previous (8Sakaki T. Akiyoshi-Shibata M. Yabusaki Y. Ohkawa H. J. Biol. Hepatic lipase (HL) and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) are key enzymes involved in the hydrolysis of triglycerides and phospholipids present in circulating plasma lipoproteins. Despite their similarities, the role that each of these two lipases play in the metabolism of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins and high density lipoproteins is distinct. In order to identify structural domains that may confer the different substrate specificities between HL and LPL, we have utilized a novel approach for performing structure-function analysis of a protein, in vivo, by using recombinant adenovirus vectors to express native and mutant enzymes in an animal model for a human genetic deficiency. HL-deficient mice (n = 19) characterized by increased plasma cholesterol and phospholipid concentrations were injected with adenovirus expressing luciferase (rLucif-AdV), native hepatic (rHL-AdV), and lipoprotein lipase (rLPL-AdV) or lipase mutants in which the lid covering the catalytic site of either enzyme was exchanged (rHL+LPL lid-AdV and rLPL+HL lid-AdV). Mice injected with rLucif-AdV had no changes in post-heparin HL and LPL activities (217 ± 29 and 7 ± 2 nmol/min/ml, respectively) as well as plasma lipids. Despite expression of similar levels of post-heparin plasma lipase activity on day 5 post-adenovirus infusion (9806 ± 915 and 9677 ± 2033 nmol/min/ml, respectively) mice injected with rHL-AdV or rHL+LPL lid-AdV demonstrated marked differences in the reduction of plasma phospholipids (70% and 32%, respectively, p < 0.005). Similarly, despite post-heparin plasma lipolytic activities of 4495 ± 534 and 4844 ± 1336 nmol/min/ml, injection of rLPL-AdV or rLPL+HL lid-AdV resulted in phospholipid reductions of 31% and 81% (p < 0.005). Exchange of the lipase lid did not significantly alter plasma triglyceride concentrations. Thus, preferential in vivo hydrolysis of phospholipids was demonstrated in animals expressing lipases containing the HL lid but not the LPL lid. These studies identify the lipase lid as a major structural motif responsible for conferring the different in vivo phospholipase activities between HL and LPL, a function which may modulate the distinct physiological roles of these two similar lipolytic enzymes in lipoprotein metabolism. The use of recombinant adenovirus to express mutant proteins in animal models for human genetic deficiencies represents a powerful, new approach for performing structure-function analysis of proteins in vivo. Most biological fluids are supersaturated with calcium salts. A mechanism controlling crystal growth is therefore necessary to prevent excessive precipitation and development of a lithiasis. In pancreatic juice, calcite precipitation is prevented by lithostathine, a glycoprotein that inhibits calcite crystal growth. We describe here the interaction of lithostathine with calcite crystals. Without lithostathine, calcite crystals grew as rhombohedra showing six {101¯4} faces. At low concentration (1 μM), lithostathine already altered crystal growth by generating new {112¯0} faces. At physiological concentrations (3-10 μM), adsorption resulted in a transition from rhombohedral to sub-cubic habits. Immunochemical localization demonstrated that, although all {101¯4} faces are equivalent, lithostathine binding was restricted to the face edges distal to the c axis. Scanning electron microscopy showed that, at the site of lithostathine binding, spreading of new CaCO3 layers during crystal growth was arrested before reaching the crystal diad axis-bearing edges. The successive kinks generated during crystal growth formed the new, striated {112¯0} faces. Similar modifications were observed with the N-terminal undecapeptide of lithostathine that bears the inhibitory activity. With 100 μM lithostathine, {112¯0} faces could reach the c axis outcrop of the former rhombohedron, resulting in an olive-shaped crystal. Finally, the number of crystals increased and their average size decreased when lithostathine concentration increased from 0.1 to 100 μM. Decreased Ca2+ concentration during crystal growth was delayed in the presence of lithostathine. It was concluded that lithostathine controls lithogenesis 1) by triggering germination of numerous calcite crystals and 2) by inhibiting the rate of Ca2+ ion apposition on the nuclei and therefore interfering with the apposition of new layers on calcite. Formation of smaller crystals, whose elimination is easier, is thereby favored. Most biological fluids are supersaturated with calcium salts. Biological fluids are generally supersaturated with respect to a calcium salt, such as oxalate in urine, phosphate in saliva, and carbonate in bile or pancreatic juice. As a result, formation of calcium salt crystals occurs spontaneously. This can be beneficial, as in the process of tooth or bone mineralization. However, it might become harmful if continuous crystal growth is allowed, leading to the formation of stones and the development of lithiasis. It is therefore essential that the precipitation of these salts is controlled. Stabilization of fluids is mainly ensured by protein inhibitors of nucleation, growth, and aggregation of crystals. Several inhibitors have been described, such as statherine in saliva (1Hay D.I. Arch. Oral Biol. 1973; 18: 1531-1541Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar), nephrocalcin in urine (2Nakagawa Y. Abram V. Kezdy F.J. Kaiser E.T. Coe F.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 12594-12600Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), gallstone protein in bile (3Shimitzu S. Sabsay B. Veis A. Ostrow J.D. Rege R.V. Dawes L.G. J. Clin. Invest. 1989; 84: 1990-1996Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), and lithostathine, originally called Pancreatic Stone Protein (PSP), in the pancreatic juice (4De Caro A. Multigner L. Lafont H. Lombardo D. Sarles H. Biochem. J. 1984; 222: 669-677Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Lebenthal E. Reber H.A. Scheele G.A. The Pancreas: Biology, Pathobiology and Disease. 2nd Ed. Raven Press, New York1993: 253Google Scholar). Gastroenterology. 1992; 103: 1277-1284Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). The N-terminal undecapeptide of the protein is essential to the inhibitory activity (7Bernard J.-P. Adrich Z. Montalto G. De Caro A. De Reggi M. Sarles H. Dagorn J.-C. Gastroenterology. 1992; 103: 1277-1284Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). Bullock W.K. Mehl J.W. Am. J. Pathol. 1950; 26: 37-55PubMed Google Scholar), showed a marked decrease in patients (9Giorgi D. Bernard J.-P. Rouquier S. Iovanna J. Sarles H. Dagorn J.-C. J. Clin. Invest. 1989; 84: 100-106Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). With lithostathine being the only protein from pancreatic juice with inhibitory activity on CaCO3 crystal growth, these results suggest that it is a key factor in the prevention of stone formation in pancreatic ducts. The present work is aimed at determining the consequences of lithostathine binding onto calcite crystals. Our results led us to propose a model of calcite growth inhibition by lithostathine. Lithostathine, a gift of Dr. J. P. Bernard, was purified from pancreatic juice of patients without chronic calcifying pancreatitis, using the procedure previously described by Montalto et al. (10Montalto G. Bonicel J. Multigner L. Rovery M. Sarles H. De Caro A. Biochem. J. 1986; 238: 227-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). Antibodies against lithostathine were raised in rabbit according to De Caro et al. (4De Caro A. Multigner L. Lafont H. Lombardo D. Sarles H. Biochem. J. 1984; 222: 669-677Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). The N-terminal undecapeptide of lithostathine, pyroEEAQTELPQAR, was synthesized at the Biotechnology Service Center (Toronto). RNase A and proteinase K were from Boehringer (Mannheim, Germany), and concanavalin A was from Sigma. We used a variant of the method originally described by Gruzenski (11Gruzenski P.M. J. Phys. Chem. Solids G. B. 1967; 1: 365-367Google Scholar). Briefly, CaCO3 crystals were grown by slow diffusion, in a dessicator, of CO2 gas from the dissociation of hydrated (NH4)2CO3 vapor into wells containing 100 μl of 7.5 mM CaCl2, pH 8, for 2 days. The slow diffusion of carbonate ions into the CaCl2 solution allows the formation of the most stable CaCO3 polymorph, i.e. calcite, at the air-water interface. The pH was checked throughout the experiment and was shown to remain between 7 and 7.5. Using the above mentioned technique, the effect of lithostathine on crystal morphology was examined by adding appropriate amounts of protein, ranging from 0.1 to 100 μM, to filtered 7.5 mM CaCl2, pH 8, prior to the onset of crystallization. Controls without lithostathine or with several other control proteins were run in parallel. Calcite crystals were then observed by optical microscopy. Crystals obtained in the presence of 1 μM lithostathine were recovered, dried, and observed by scanning electron microscopy. The same experiments were run with the N-terminal undecapeptide of lithostathine that bears the inhibitory activity on CaCO3 crystal growth (7Bernard J.-P. Adrich Z. Montalto G. De Caro A. De Reggi M. Sarles H. Dagorn J.-C. Gastroenterology. 1992; 103: 1277-1284Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar), except that peptide concentration ranged from 10 μM to 10 mM. Control experiments were performed with three proteins apparently devoid of activity on crystal growth. RNase A, proteinase K, and concanavalin A were used at concentrations of 0.1, 1, 10, and 100 μM. Free Ca2+ ion concentrations in the supersaturated solution was monitored during crystal growth in the absence or in the presence of 3 μM lithostathine. Briefly, 10-μl aliquots were withdrawn at different time intervals and mixed to 5 ml of Ca2+-depleted water. The Ca2+ concentration was measured with an ionization flame atomic absorption spectrometer (SpectrAA-20, Varian, Australia). A standard reference curve with a known amount of Ca2+ was made in the same conditions. Specific binding of lithostathine onto calcite crystals was determined by immunofluorescence as follows. Calcite crystals formed in the presence of 1 μM lithostathine were washed twice with 100 μl of 7.5 mM CaCl2, pH 8. Then, calcite crystals were incubated for 1 h with rabbit anti-serum to lithostathine diluted 10 times with 50 μl of 7.5 mM CaCl2, pH 8. Wells were then washed with 100 μl of the CaCl2 solution and incubated for 1 h with anti-rabbit fluoresceine isothiocyanate-labeled goat antibodies, diluted at 1/160, in 50 μl of the CaCl2 solution. After several washes, crystals were observed under a fluorescence microscope. Controls with or without lithostathine or antibodies were run and treated in parallel. Optical microscopy examination was performed with an Orthomat microscope (Leitz Wetzlar, Germany) at magnifications up to ×200. Scanning electron microscopy analysis was carried out using a Jeol 35C microscope, operated at 25 kV. Dried crystal batches were mounted on metal stubs, coated with a thin gold layer of about 600-800 Å by ion sputtering. The resolution was 60 Å. The micrographs were produced with secondary electrons. Considering the trigonal and diad axes of calcite, which determine specific symmetry properties, these observations suggest the existence of six newly born faces belonging to the {112¯0} form. This is partly shown on Fig. 6B with the {2¯110} face. Thus, the inhibition of growth by lithostathine occurs by generating new faces organized as a “zigzag” ring running normal to the triad axis (see also Fig. 8). With the progressive arrest of growth, the steps stacked on each other, thereby forming macrosteps close to the upper edge of the {112¯0} faces (the intersection of two contiguous edges linked by the obtuse angle). Striated facets appeared on such angles. Fig. 7 also shows details of the microtopography of the new prismatic faces.
